reviewText: I had so much fun with this game! I recommend this for Harry Potter fans only - as you won't understand what's happening if you haven't read the books and seen the movies. The puzzles can get tricky. I got badly stuck quite a few times, but my solution was always the same - destroy EVERYTHING. Maybe this is common idea with LEGO games? I'm not sure, because this is my first. Either way, I immensely enjoyed the artistic style of the world, the somewhat open-world layout, and the hilarious LEGO retelling of the stories. If we had stars to give, I'd give it 5.

reviewText:
Played Lego HP 1-4, and now finished the story here.

The game really improves on year 1-4. Everything is better now. From more special abilities, to better menus.
After finishing the story, you have to re-visit everything with new characters to find all the hidden stuff!
I really wish more games could be like Lego games.

Marvelous gameplay, charming graphics, excellent attention to details... Simply PERFECT!

11/10

reviewText:
Lego Harry Potter Years 5-7 was the first thing I installed after playing through the first one (1-4). I wanted  to see how the story would continue, and since this game came out years after the first one, I expected graphical improvements and other nice features. I though this was gonna be another funny game to play. I think that's actually correct, but performance keeps me off this game.

Funny thing is, for a lot of players with low-end graphics card this game runs good. For me, using a Nvidia gtx 980 however, game does not. I played for a few hours, really tried to like this game, but when framerate dips between 60 and down to below 10, it's really hard to do so.

Normally I would just wait to write a review until the problem is fixed, but since this game was released in 2012, I don't think they will ever update it properly. It's sad to see, since the graphical improvements over the first game is great and everything about the dark and gritty wizard world is also nice.

There is a lack of harry potter games available, so it's sad when the ones available aren't great either. It's even worse when the game has potential, but it dragged down by poor performance. It's a little wierd too, because the first one (released in 2008) runs great on new high-end graphics card.

I got dizzy playing this game so I had to quit it, which sucks, since I really like both LEGO and Harry Potter franchise. I wanna recommend this game, but I really can't do that, unless you are running an old machine or if you have an xbox 360 to play it on.

reviewText:
Well, I'm a huge fan of LEGO games: LEGO Hobbit, Marvel, The Movie, Star Wars: The Complete Saga and ( of course ) this game itself are all in my Steam library and this has been just as good as the others ( better, in some cases ). This game summed up a journey I had been on since I played LEGO Harry Potter Years 1-4 years ago in 2010 on my Nintendo Wii and I must say that this has been a great way to finally finish the adventure five years later!

Plot:

The game goes through the last 3 Harry Potter books and the last four films. You get to play through 24 levels of magical mayhem, each story consisting of six levels a lesson or two and some free roaming in the open world. Fans of HP and his amazing adventures will be enthralled to see LEGO's comedic twists on the story and to discover references to both the books and the films, from obvious ones like locations and characters, to tiny ones like the objects characters will sometimes hold for a few seconds if you watch them closely ( e.g every minute or so Neville Longbottom will get out a plant, stroke it for a few seconds and then put it away, this is a reference to the Mimbulus Mimbletonia he owns in the Order Of The Pheonix book.

Gameplay:

There is lots of magical gameplay to experience and 7 spells to unlock:

Wingardium Leviosa

Lumos

Diffindo

Aquamenti ( yes I looked it up )

Focus ( The spell Snape uses to get inside Harry's mind in Order of the Pheonix )

Expecto Patronum

Reducto

These spells allow characters to break special objects, levitate things, spray water, create objects out of red brick, light up areas and defeat all sorts of magical beings. There is also a brilliant feature where instead of an 8th spell, you get a special pet, animagus, or just object that that character possesses (e.g. Harry has his Invis Cloak, Hermione has Crookshanks the cat and Remus Lupin has the power to turn into a werewolf ). Another good feature to note is the fact that 5-7 has added duels. This allows you to fight against many characters by using spells you have collected. You must use these to shield yourself, or try to defeat your opponent. These duels are a key part of the 5-7 levels, so you'll have lots of time to prepare yourself for the grand finale: Harry vs Voldermort in Deathly Hallows pt. 2. Between levels you will be able to explore one, two or all three of the main hubs. The main hubs are as follows:

Hogwarts Castle

London

A small part of the countryside, used to represent Harry, Ron and Hermione's trek in Deathly Hallows Part 1

Each hub has lots to do and extras to collect, for instance, London does not only include the Muggle part, but also The Leaky Cauldron and both Diagon and Knockturn alley. The free roam world does alter depending on which of the four stories you are currently playing in:

Order Of The Pheonix is a sunny, safe environment with racy, peaceful and happy music.

Half Blood Prince has a darker environment and Death Eaters can attack you at moments in both the alleys and The Leaky Cauldron. It also has a slightly sadder tune in the background.

Deathly Hallows Part 1 has a rainy and very dark environment with lots of common Death Eater attacks in both the Muggle and Wizarding parts of London. Hogwarts is only able to explore via the Marauder's map and you have to play as Neville, Ginny or Seamus.

Deathly Hallows Part 2 has a dangerous environment before you defeat Voldermort, where Death Eaters attack in London, both the alleys and even Hogwarts. After you defeat Voldermort, the open world becomes safe and sunny with slightly sad music in the background.

reviewText:
Harry Potter's innocent days are over. The boarding school antics have trickled to a halt, classrooms have gone silent, and even Quidditch matches--once the mark of happier times--have fallen by the wayside. In their place, a much darker picture has taken shape, marked by the ever-increasing fear of death. As far as stories go, it's not exactly a walk in the park, but it's nothing that a good Lego sense of humour can't handle.

Like its predecessor, Lego Harry Potter: Years 5-7 excels at finding the true heart of the story it is trying to tell, layering this otherwise bleak premise with its own particular brand of cheekiness without sacrificing the essence of J.K. Rowling's world. This is a fun, richly detailed game that rewards curiosity and offers plenty of gameplay variety, making it well worth the effort for Lego and Harry Potter fans alike.

Lego Harry Potter: Years 5-7 weaves together events from the final three Harry Potter books and the final four films. Despite the necessary liberties taken to mesh three narratives into one, the game manages to employ a multifaceted structure that is easy to navigate: each of the four chapters of the game is divided into smaller subchapters, each comprising a new part of the story. While the Vita version is a slightly simplified version of the console game (for example, cutscenes sometimes replace extended gameplay sequences, and some activities are different), it loses none of the charm.

The gameplay is consistent with past Lego games: each short level requires you to complete a series of puzzle-solving tasks using a range of character abilities while knocking down and rebuilding large parts of the environment. There are also myriad side missions, quests, and collectibles. While the game's story moves along with effortless charm, it's the collectible element that adds both variety and replay value.

There's a certain kind of addictive satisfaction that comes with collecting absolutely everything, and the game rewards this interactivity in a multitude of ways: 200 gold bricks, 24 school emblems, 20 cheats, and the fulfilment of becoming a True Wizard" stud collector. It's also smart about the way it does this: only a proper playthrough unlocks all the characters and their respective abilities

This well-maintained lighthearted tone--a hallmark of all Lego games--is possible here due in large part to the attention to detail paid in the game's design.\n\nThe game's environments are well detailed and contextually accurate

The cutscenes re-create some of the film series' most inspired moments; the opening scene of Half-Blood Prince is a particularly fine example of this. They succeed in doing justice to the story's darker tone through the expertly crafted flashback sequences which are presented in a striking
column26: sepia-toned aesthetic that reflects the maturity of the source material.\n\nBut it's not all smooth sailing. The loading times can be a bit of a bore
column27: especially since the game requires a substantial amount of time to load even when you're walking in between rooms and scenes. There's also a slight inconsistency with some of the game's smaller tasks
column28: which are inserted at various moments throughout the story but have little bearing on what's happening. This is irksome only during the particularly high-tension moments
column29: some of which are peppered with a number of bafflingly mundane activities
column30: like building a cart or collecting ingredients for a potion. Thankfully
column31: these moments are infrequent.\n\nFor those who aren't ready to say good-bye to Harry Potter just yet
column32: Lego Harry Potter: Years 5-7 is a charming way to stay inside J.K. Rowling's magical world a little bit longer. Despite the occasional slipup
column33: the game successfully builds on the original story to offer a simple yet satisfying experience that has depth and replay value. There's enough to engage and have fun with to appeal to fans of Harry Potter as well as fans of previous Lego games."

reviewText: This is an astoundingly good game.  If you enjoyed the books and/or movies, you'll love the Lego counterparts. reviewText:
Lego Harry Potter: Years 5-7 is yet another licensed Lego game and a sequel to Years 1-4. As you can masterfully detuct, it's based on the movies of the last three years of Harry Potter. And yes, the last one is divided into two parts in the game too. Developed by Traveller's Tales and released in 2011. Nope, no talking yet. Nope, still never-ever online multiplayer.

It also was released for Xbox 360, PS3, Wii, NDS, 3DS, PSP, Vita, iOS. From the main consoles you can guess that Wii has the worse graphics. However PC doesn't come as the best, as it's not optimised and they don't sell DLC for it like for consoles: DLC pack of 10 characters and DLC pack of 5 silly magic to shoot at honest people. It doesn't sound important though.

NDS, 3DS, PSP, Vita and iOS are also interesting to mention. As usual, Traveller's Tales can't decide what kind of Lego game to make for portable systems. Years 1-4 had some kind of isometric fetch quest with characters telling you things in dialog box. Years 5-7 seems to be made from scratch and made itself to be like a cutted down version of main game, while occasionally doing unique things. Single-player, yea. It is however nasty that PS Vita was forced to have as much of content as Nintendo DS, despite being much more powerful.

Technically, PC version comes with bunch of problems.
First of all, it's not optimized. Many people reported to have low framerates. Some have it only at start of levels, others have it constantly. Be ready that you may not run it smoothly.
And another one is control mapping. The game doesn't remember them and you will have to rebind buttons on each game's launch. I also had a minor glitch where when I chose USB controller the game would show me square characters instead of words like button" or "axis".
At least it doesn't freeze or lose save or make progress impossible like Years 1-4 for some people.

Gameplay-wise
voteText: collect-a-thon. That was before characters talked. It still has a hub world of Hogwards and some story missions take place in it instead of separate levels. Mostly for classes. And yes

reviewText: Local co-op is fun for a few hours, but the game is terribly repetitive. Expect no action and lots of blindly smashing stuff until you have satisfied the game's nonsensical puzzle requirements.

reviewText:
Unlike the previous Harry Potter Lego, this game's jokes are a bit off-putting. Especailly if a fan of the book. Some are hilarious, but others fall short, but that's a problem with how much darker the source material got and the people who made this game trying to get in jokes and hilarious moments in the sensitive and depressing scenes of the series such as the death of various main characters.

The last two years are a massive pain with Death Eaters appearing everywhere and then causing you damage by shooting you and getting mobed by them. This is a cause of frustraition, however as this mostly happens in the last part of the game then you don't lose any studs when you get killed which is very suiting.

As I managed to unlock the x4 multiplier I've managed to get enough studs to afford anything and make completeing this game 100% so much easier.

I really can't wait to play the Marvel Lego heroes game.

reviewText:
I was really excited to get this, especially on sale.
Point blank, it doesn't work like a pc game, and it barely works at all.
There is no mouse support, so that makes moving and targeting hell. Not the breaking point, however.
THE GAME DOES NOT SAVE.
There is no manual saving feature, and after going through three full scene changes, there was no autosaving performed either.
It records gameplay time, but no autosaving done and I am so mad I'm repeating myself.
I don't know what to do, honestly. It doesn't function as a pc game should.

reviewText:
At least this LEGO game works on a Haswell i5 LE Custom Gaming rig using AMD Graphics cards connected to a 1080p Tv.

The following LEGO games (if you have i5 Haswell & AMD Graphics cards) dont work and just dont begin to launch.

1) Lego The Movie.
2) Lego Marvel Super Heroes.
3) Lego The Hobbit.

A quick flash of a box indicating `the game is about to launch` then DEAD & back to Steam.

The other 7 or 8 Lego games do work; but not the 3 listed.
voteText: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I cannot in good faith recommend this game. It has everything that all of the previous LEGO games have, but it also comes with its own problems. The main one is that it can be incredibly boring. A few of the missions just don't have anything going on with them. No enemies, no plot points, nothing. Then when the game realizes that you probably should have enemies, it spams you with them, so you literally have to stop everything you're doing every few seconds to beat them. It gets repetitive, and shows that the game developers don't realize that there's a big difference between challenging and annoying.

The makers of Candy Crush also have no idea what that line is, but whatever.

Also, all of the best LEGO games have humor, or, at the very least, characterize their characters pretty well. They're fun to watch. That is not the case with this one. I didn't really care about any of them.

Most of the levels feel like busywork instead of actual levels that advance the story. Heck, some of the levels in between the levels that weren't really levels were more interesting than the levels we got.

I'd say that, if the game got one more re-write for the story, it could have been a lot better. As it was, it had a few glaring problems. I'd say no to this one.

Apparently this game was not optimized to the PC at all, i have a fairly good PC rig and i keep getting fps drops
(to like 10-15 fps) and my CPU usage keeps jumping from 15% to 60%, lowering the graphics is not helping at all
and in all these years they never bothered to patch it.
Please dont support the developers by buying this game, there are plenty more LEGO games you can play.

reviewText:
It seems like it could be a great game, but the incredibly poor optimizations ruin it.

My specs:
Intel Core i7 4770 @ 3.40GHz
16.0GB Dual-Channel DDR3 @ 800MHz
3071MB NVIDIA GeForce GTX 780 (EVGA)

I was averaging around 25-40fps throughout most of the game.  I was getting a solid 60fps with vsync on in the previous LEGO Harry Potter game.  Unless there's a future patch (which I highly doubt will happen), I wouldn't recommend this.

reviewText: A fun game, combining Lego and Harry Potter again.  However, it suffers from even worse technical glitches than its predecessor.  I had to uninstall the game after it caused multiple blue screens and even a computer restart.  I got to a part in the last year of the game that seemed to trigger these events everytime I reached it, to the point where I could no longer continue.  Rather than risk damaging my computer, I uninstalled it.

reviewText: Although this games works 100% I can't recommend it because years 1-4 fails to work at all and this is clearly an issue a lot of people have had with years 1-4. And a major failure in this game is the complete lack of dialogue, the game may look like Harry Potter but it sure as heck doesn't feel like when you're playing it with the characters just moaning and groaning the whole time, I played for 30mins and just couldn't stand it anymore. I should have researched the games better here on Steam to discover the problems people have had and to find out there's no dialogue from the movies so it's my own fault that I wasted money on these games. At least LEGO Lord of The Rings is MUCH MUCH better!

reviewText: stupid fun but a the bus are a little annoying
Alot better gameplay than the first. Not as glitchy either, although there is the odd bug they are far and few between. Not a bad game to get if you can grab it while its on sale.

This game is amazing! It's the story that you know and love with a light-hearted twist that makes character interaction and cutscenes to be so funny. You can set out to play for an hour and easily make it to 5 hours without knowing.\n\n9/10

I'll say one thing about this game right from the start and that is that my feelings on it are quite mixed in some aspects.

The gameplay and graphics are vastly improved from Years 1-4 plus the area you can explore is simply GINORMOUS and I found the humor to be quite good overall.

It's said humor though why my feelings are mixed as it often ends up creating a great mood whiplash.

For example, during Year 7 Part 2 (the game follows the movies to create four chapters same as in years 1-4) in the part where Harry and the others find Snape dying it at first seems to be played seriously with a very different and sober track playing but by the end of it they SHOVE HIS HEAD INTO A BARREL to get the memory (about him having loved Lily and working as a double-agent for Dumbledore) and then Harry and the lot happily walk out.

That said, I may be taking things to seriously with this game since it is a LEGO game after all but in my opinion the darker parts of the HP story just don't translate well at all.
(Looking back at the end of Year 4 in Y1-4 and cringing hard)

Nice game but play for the jokes and the interpretation of the story, not the original story.

If you like LEGO games and you love Harry Potter, buy this game. No achievements, but I didn't mind at all. Exploring Hogwarts, the grounds, and all the other places you venture to is so much fun. Finding all the secret items is really fun and makes me feel like I am really a wizard using these powers.\n\n10/10, will replay again!

This game is amazing! It's the story that you know and love with a light-hearted twist that makes character interaction and cutscenes to be so funny. You can set out to play for an hour and easily make it to 5 hours without knowing.\n\n9/10

I don't know why many gamers can't get this game running, luckily it works on my pc and I'm happy to play it because it is so well made!! The scenes recreates almost exactly the movie and characters are also funny!
It can be tedious sometimes to smash all the bricks or defeat bosses but overall I would recommend this game to anyone who likes Harry Potter.
It's much more and more and more and more enjoyable if played with firends in local Co-op!
I didn't try with 2x Keyboard or 2x Xbox360 controller, I play it with a keyboard and a controller and they works great simultaneously.

The only issue of this game is that sometimes the keys change layout or lose the configuration, good that there's only a few key to map, each time the game starts. But it only happens at the beginning I noticed, now I play it without mapping 'em again.

yes, would recommend it!

Harry Potter (and Voldemort) meet LEGO for the final time in years five to seven, right before Potters' big graduation from Hogwartz. This installment is significantly better than the last, and for a great many reasons. You'll have the chance to play through the final movie installments ranging from London to Hogwartz, and you'll encounter infinitely more interesting foes and friends.

The lack of voice acting may be equally as shameful as it's predecessor, but it's not missed in this one as the immersion is outstanding. In this game you'll feel a part of the world and all of it's charm, you'll find a beautiful artistic direction which embraces the darker nature of the story. You'll also for the first time get to play through history, and as the three men in the story of the dealthly hallows.

The mechanics are a lot better and more interesting and they feature a dueling mechanic which could feature as it's own game it's that much fun. In a Kame Hameha style want battle, though it was extremely badly implemented in the original, the sequel has refined this fantastic ability.

If you enjoy LEGO games, if you like Harry Potter, you'll definitely enjoy this title. It gets to a point where you're almost taking as many screenshots as you may in the Hobbit and LOTR LEGO titles.

Love it!

I have some trouble with the Crest on Magic is Might"

Harry Potter (and Voldemort) meet LEGO for the final time in years five to seven, right before Potters' big graduation from Hogwartz. This installment is significantly better than the last, and for a great many reasons. You'll have the chance to play through the final movie installments ranging from London to Hogwartz, and you'll encounter infinitely more interesting foes and friends.

The lack of voice acting may be equally as shameful as it's predecessor, but it's not missed in this one as the immersion is outstanding. In this game you'll feel a part of the world and all of it's charm, you'll find a beautiful artistic direction which embraces the darker nature of the story. You'll also for the first time get to play through history, and as the three men in the story of the dealthly hallows.

The mechanics are a lot better and more interesting and they feature a dueling mechanic which could feature as it's own game it's that much fun. In a Kame Hameha style want battle, though it was extremely badly implemented in the original, the sequel has refined this fantastic ability.

If you enjoy LEGO games, if you like Harry Potter, you'll definitely enjoy this title. It gets to a point where you're almost taking as many screenshots as you may in the Hobbit and LOTR LEGO titles.

I'll say one thing about this game right from the start and that is that my feelings on it are quite mixed in some aspects.

The gameplay and graphics are vastly improved from Years 1-4 plus the area you can explore is simply GINORMOUS and I found the humor to be quite good overall.

It's said humor though why my feelings are mixed as it often ends up creating a great mood whiplash.

For example, during Year 7 Part 2 (the game follows the movies to create four chapters same as in years 1-4) in the part where Harry and the others find Snape dying it at first seems to be played seriously with a very different and sober track playing but by the end of it they SHOVE HIS HEAD INTO A BARREL to get the memory (about him having loved Lily and working as a double-agent for Dumbledore) and then Harry and the lot happily walk out.

That said, I may be taking things to seriously with this game since it is a LEGO game after all but in my opinion the darker parts of the HP story just don't translate well at all.

Yet another superfun Lego Game! I could recommend it to everyone that likes Harry Potter. Only thing is, the control always revert to their original settings whenever I start the game.

My experience is heavily biased by having just finished years 1-4.  It's not a *bad* game... it's just not as enjoyable as the first game.  There's nothing specifically awful, it's just that every aspect of gameplay feels slower or has little niggles that make it more awkward and interrupt the flow of destruction.\n\nI wanted to get all the collectables in the first game, this one just felt like a chore.
Fun game like all LEGO games. Great for sofa play with controllers.

First level: the playing grounds. You need to build stairs to get on a higher level. Simple enough right? No. The building blocks decided to click into each other the wrong way. Then I tried to separate them but apparently they're stuck to each other. I minimize the game (alt tab) to look on google on how to separate these blocks. The game crashes because apparently you're not allowed to minimize it. Current mood:  not in the mood to play anymore.

Liked:
Levels were fun
New mechanics that previous Lego games didn't have
Decent graphics (for a Lego game)
Large over-world with collectibles
Characters were unlocked by finding them in levels

Disliked:
Poorly optimized (huge frame dips from over 300fps down to 30fps)
Resets keyboard controls every time you relaunch
skipping cutscenes sometimes didn't work
Great way to finish off the Lego Harry Potter series. It is a little buggy with the Red Bricks though.

This is the first LEGO game I've ever played and I absolutely love it. I purchased it last Monday and by Wednesday I had already completed the story. So far I'm working on unlocking everything. I loved the gameplay and the humor elements they added were great.\nThe only issues I have is the wonky controls, where you have to work hard to get vehicles to do what you want and to get your character to go in the correct direction, and the fact that they cut out some important things like all of the deaths in Deathly Hallows.\nBesides that, the game is fun and I would definitely recommend it!

if you play lego games and like harry potter this is the best sequel to any of the series
Perfect family game. The best fun will be in two players cooperation.
I love it so much!\nThe only problem I have with it is my mouse doesn't work in game play.
Alot better gameplay than the first. Not as glitchy either, although there is the odd bug they are far and few between. Not a bad game to get if you can grab it while its on sale.
Not too bad a game, it's entertaining. They could've done a lot with it but, at least it's humorous.
Awesome lego  games are the best
I like it that the game is not exactly like the movies, and even in the serious parts it still try to keep the humor.

This game in the series becomes harder to recommend than the first. Stuttery frame rates on a 4k series I7 tied with a GTX 780ti shows poor optimization (tried with a variety of drivers to the same effect). Also, the story telling just felt off, with both me and my wife (who have read all the books and films) feeling slightly confused about what is going on.

The other big let down is, a heck of a lot of assets from the first game have been re-used, making the whole game feel like an add on and repetitive. We also managed to get our characters or important objects stuck in scenery, and unable to progress revealing game breaking bugs. Having to restart a level a third time because of this lowered the fun levels deep into the frustrating.

Compared with newer Lego titles like LOTR, this game holds no candle. Buggy, un-optimized, rehash feel that has no chance of me ever going back to get 100%.

Would only recommend to die hard fans, and even then only just. For everyone else, there are much better games in the family co-op genre out there. 6/10
There is ot much to say. The authors used every trick available and they gave us a full Harry Potter experiance. Great job, I had loads of fun playing it.

A Spectacular sequel to LEGO Harry Potter Years 1-4.

Return to the magical wizarding world of Harry Potter to continue the magnificent journey along with Harry, Ron and Hermione. Go through the stories of Order of the Pheonix, Half Blood Prince and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 and 2. Everything this time around is better, the spells are more pretty, the graphics now has Shaders, less loading times and bigger levels, Play as a multitude of characters just like the last game and more!

There are more gameplay features and characters have more unique options to complete a level. This is a very fun and great game if you loved Years 1-4, this game has the fantastic updated soundtrack making you experience wonderful memories of watching the movies or reading the books.

This game however deals with darker themes but it does sugar coat it with it's hilarious cutscenes of lego. Must have if you love Harry Potter, Magic or anything fun.
Great Game,It Was Short,But Probably The Best Lego Game I Have Played In A While,I just dun like how it follows the movies

What a disappointment!!! I was so looking forward to this game after the amazing years 1-4, but I couldn't even get past the second scene without giving up.

My problems:
- which idiot decided to change the control settings from game 1 to game 2???
- everything that's within a few steps from where you are is blurred............. and gets unblurred when you get closer........... talk about a migraine trigger
- the camera changes angles at the most inconvenient moments :X
- Harry has conveniently forgotten all his spells from years 1-4 except for one, even the ones gotten through the storyline.......

Honestly, this game should have been a breeze and enjoyable after getting the hang of years 1-4, yet I feel like I'm playing a completely different game, which is not quite what I was expecting. The blurring thing and the changing camera angles is a serious deal-breaker.

Like most Lego titles, I definitely enjoyed this one. I really enjoy the recent push to make the game more about exploring places, such as Hogwarts and London, rather just than completing levels. This really makes the games more fun and interesting in large worlds such as: LOTR and the Marvel Lego games.
Too bad this one is based off the movies and not the books. Some of the levels seem pretty trivial and pointless, but the later HP books and movies could be a little too dark for a Lego game.

This is a port of a console game from 2011. The controls are alright, it's buggy in places, and it looks a little outdated. But the Potterhead in me couldn't put it down. Even after completing the game, I had to go back and find all of the extra easter eggs, unlock more characters, etc. I definitely recommend this to fans of the Harry Potter books and/or movies - otherwise, probably not worth your time. Try to catch it on sale for $5-$10.
